posts.name: Seth Nelsen
posts.cooked:
So we are stuck.  We are using last year’s swerve drive that worked (despite hardware issues at times) but this year it is dead.  Cannot get it do drive consistently.  We are using YAGSL for the first time, CTR CANcoders (PHOENIX 6), NEOs, Sparkmax, on MK4.  We (like so many others) cannot get the offsets to give us consistent control of the robot.  Initially we can go forward, backward, right, left (nominally) but then we cannot rotate and swerve modules start to go wacky.  We have one swerve drive that doesn’t seem to spin the wheel as easily and cannot diagnose the hardware issue.  Please if you can give a clear guide to help us with YAGSL , perhaps you know of a common issue we are missing.  Getting desperate!!!  We have gotten our swerve to drive the last two years (PHOENIX 5 being the big difference) but we are getting worse instead of better.  PLEASE HELP!

I am not a coder, but here is our teams’ code

GitHub - team3042/Reefscape-2025: FRC code for the 2025 FIRST Robotics season FRC code for the 2025 FIRST Robotics season

FRC code for the 2025 FIRST Robotics season

link_counts.title: GitHub - team3042/Reefscape-2025: FRC code for the 2025 FIRST Robotics season

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
stnelsen:

rotate and swerve modules start to go wacky

Could you elaborate on this? Ideally with a video or pictures. Thanks for providing your code from the outset.

As far as nothing obvious and a constant source of “friction” in the system: this can sometimes be down to motors or bearings going bad.

Here are some additional troubleshooting steps.

posts.name: Seth Nelsen
posts.cooked: No videos, but basically angles to drive become erratic.  You can drive forward, backward, relatively left and right with results you expect.  However, over time direction becomes off. i.e. left becomes forward, goes wrong way, cannot rotate drivetrain as swerves go all sorts of angles.  I did just notice my students have the NAVX ported wrong in the code.  they have NAVX_SPI but I am feeling they should have “navx_mxp_serial”  its directly plugged into the  top port on the roborio.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
stnelsen:

i.e. left becomes forward, goes wrong way, cannot rotate drivetrain as swerves go all sorts of angles.

If you try to spin in place:

Do the modules snap to angles they shouldn’t (e.g., you expect them to point 40 degrees but they point to 135 degrees instead? ( in other words some of them are 90 degrees off of you try to rotate in place))

If so, my money is the CAN IDs do not map to the physical corners of the bot.

stnelsen:

over time direction becomes off

However, this makes me think you have wrong ratios/ conversion factors somewhere.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
We’re using the same hardware I think. Our repo is open. I’m pretty sure this is the config directory we’re using (despite the name being the name of a fall off-season event; we’re testing 2025 with the 2024 fall version of the bot).

Ours works well enough swerve-wise.

Edit to add: Notably, we have “inverted:angle” true and you have it false on your modules, which is something that working methodically through the bring-up flowchart would have revealed, so maybe you missed something, or maybe there’s a legitimate reason for the difference, but there’s a difference.

posts.name: Seth Nelsen
posts.cooked: Angles of modules on rotate look random.  Maybe one or two in correct direction, but other dragging. CAN IDs are all correct for CANcoders. Can you elaborate on ratios and conversion factors?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: See the “edit to add” in my prior. (I was trying to avoid another post, but now I don’t want you to miss it thinking you’ve already read that post.)

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Ensure the magnets are properly retained (super glue or green Loctite (retaining compound))

Although if it works on bot restart this likely isn’t the issue

posts.name: Seth Nelsen
posts.cooked:
Angles are always consistent in phoenix tuner, but one module has me suspicious.  I had capable students assemble these, but likely should have been more involved.

Thanks for all these insights.  I am going to start with the NAVX port issue I believe I have found.  Then follow the flowchart through the various items you mentioned.  Does someone have a step by step guide for the correct angle offsets.  Phoenix 6 is different than phoenix 5 and we are always second guessing ourselves vs other directions.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: We only have access to the robot on school days, but if you’re still stuck on Monday afternoon, post back here and I can ask my programming team if they have time to try your code and see if it behaves well or poorly on our dev bot. (Alternatively, download and try our code, which should at least drive around for you [after you match up the CAN IDs, of course], assuming that the lack of vision hardware/updates over NT won’t be an issue for our code on your bot.)

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Dig through the YAGSL page, there are a few things that should help!

posts.name: Ramón
posts.cooked: This could be a mechanical issue, we’ve had issues specifically with the MK4 SDS Swerve module where the turn motor pinion would become loose since it’s glued in place and would throw off the angle measurement, however this should only happen if you’re polling the NEO integrated encoder for the angle, it shouldn’t happen when polling the CANcoder. The angles could also be off because Phoenix 6 2025 transitioned to returning Angle measures which need to be treated accordingly.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: We had the same issues last year and since gone back too the MK4i’s . SDS does make an upgrade kit if you had the cash to move from them to MK4i’s. Most teams aren’t using MK4’s anymore and it will be easier to fix at events where other teams are using the same modules as you. At least the majority do here in NE
